body_html: Every TensorFlow operation (tf.Variable, tf.add, even t1 * t2 when t1 and t2 are tensors) creates, in the background, an op that is stored in the graph. So if you write y = t1 * t2 then you're creating an Mul-Op in the global TF graph. It all happens in the background, you can look in python/framework/ops.py if you want to know more. The graph is created (and can be changed) in the with tf.Graph().as_default(): context.
body_text: Every TensorFlow operation (tf.Variable, tf.add, even t1 * t2 when t1 and t2 are tensors) creates, in the background, an op that is stored in the graph. So if you write y = t1 * t2  then you're creating an Mul-Op in the global TF graph. It all happens in the background, you can look in python/framework/ops.py if you want to know more. The graph is created (and can be changed) in the with tf.Graph().as_default(): context.
body: Every TensorFlow operation (tf.Variable, tf.add, even t1 \* t2 when t1 and t2 are tensors) creates, in the background, an op that is stored in the graph. So if you write y = t1 \* t2  then you're creating an Mul-Op in the global TF graph. It all happens in the background, you can look in python/framework/ops.py if you want to know more. The graph is created (and can be changed) in the with tf.Graph().as_default(): context.
